awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of microscopy equipment to enhance histological research in Forensic Anthropology, Biology, and Bioarchaeology
awd_abstract_narration:
With Major Research Instrumentation support, Sophia Mavroudas and her collaborators will purchase an integrated microscopy imaging and data analysis suite that consists of a Leica DM6M compound microscope and Leica M205C Stereoscope, both with internal cameras that are connected to a central workstation with an associated Leica Aperio ScanScope CS2 slide scanner.  This will enhance Texas State University's research and outreach programs in forensic anthropology, biology, and bioarchaeology. This microscopy imaging suite is a user-friendly system that will impact the large group of students and researchers, from the undergraduate through to the postdoctoral level, who are part of the Forensic Anthropology Center at Texas State (FACTS) at Texas State University, a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI). As an asset of FACTS, this equipment will foster synergistic collaborative research and interactive teaching.  The addition of the microscopy suite will elevate the new PhD in Applied Anthropology Program and enhance faculty and student federally funded research in forensic anthropology, biology, and archaeology. The associated activities include the scientific training of women and underrepresented groups in histology and surface imaging, undergraduate STEM training, graduate student research and professionalization, and the expansion of FACTS workshops to include histology and surface imaging. 


The microscopy suite will allow for fast imaging of a variety of samples from 1x-1000x at one workstation which consists of the DM6M compound microscope, M205C stereosmicroscope, and Aperio ScopScan CS 2. This will be used to capture evidence from skeletal trauma, zooarchaeological samples, and artifact assemblages. Combined with existing FACTS resources, this equipment will support innovative experimental studies including controlled human decomposition experiments that can model the microscopic diagenesis of human bone throughout the post-mortem interval, as well as macroscopic trauma investigation from vulture scavenging. The associated stereoscope with imaging software will also allow for novel and detailed 3D modeling of skeletal trauma and pathology from documented collections as well as forensic casework and bioarchaeological samples. The acquisition of this equipment will help build and make available to researchers the first ever referential catalog of histological human variation from the rapidly expanding Texas State University Donated Skeletal Collection (TXSTDSC). The microscopy system will enable FACTS to build on existing research programs that focus on bone histology in various contexts including the investigation of human vs nonhuman bone differentiation, histological mammal species identification, human ageing, dental histology season-of-death estimation, dental histology studies of pathology and stress, the application of GIS technology to study bone histomorphology, and histological human variation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary aim of the project, “MRI: Acquisition of Microscopy Equipment to Enhance Histological Research in Forensic Anthropology, Biology, and Bioarchaeology” was to purchase a microscopy suite consisting of a Leica DM6M microscope, Leica M205 C stereoscope, and a Leica Aperio CS2 Scanner to be used as shared equipment for use in forensic anthropological, biological, and bioarchaeological research. The project also provided funding for two histology technicians as well as two graduate assistants and an undergraduate assistant over the two-year timeline.

Situated within the Forensic Anthropology Center at Texas State (FACTS), the equipment provides continued support for ongoing medicolegal investigations that come through the laboratory and allows FACTS to conduct consultations for histological casework of medicolegal significance from across the country. The cost share funds from Texas State University provided support for a histology technician to develop Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for equipment training and begin to develop the FACTS Comparative Histology Collection from the documented Texas State Donated Skeletal Collection (TXSTDSC) housed in the same laboratory. Over the two years of the project timeline two histology technicians as well as two graduate assistants and an undergraduate assistant were hired to assist with SOP preparation, slide making, and data collection.

In two years, the project has produced four detailed SOPs for equipment usage and sample preparation, 728 slides from the TXSTDSC, 1,318 slides total from TXST and solicited resources, and a database of histological data and catalogued images for research and student instruction. Although delayed by the COVID-19 pandemic and associated university restrictions, research into the relationship between histomorphological structures and life history variables as well as experimental histotaphonomy projects have begun and preliminary results have been accepted for presentations at national conferences. One thesis and one dissertation have already been completed using the equipment and three additional dissertations are underway. The images generated from the microscopy suite have been used in classroom instruction, workshops for non-scientists interested in bone biology and anthropology, outreach for local schools and community groups, as well as virtual lectures for individuals across the United States.

The presence of the microscopy suite within FACTS at Texas State University (a Hispanic Serving Institution) has directly increased practical STEM learning opportunities for females and traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM since the makeup of Texas State University’s undergraduate population is 56.7% non-white and FACTS graduate student body is 90% female, 39% of which are females of color. A formal internship for histology at Texas State using the equipment has been established and will continue past the timeline of this project. Overall, the microscopy suite has made significant contributions to the education of students, research, teaching, community outreach, and medicolegal investigations. The microscopy suite and its products will continue to be used by faculty and students in collaborative cross-disciplinary projects in the years to come.
